segments.text: One of the pioneering efforts in that direction has been made by the great physiologist, marine physiologist, Professor Schollander, here at Scripps, who has demonstrated that the most difficult experiments can be carried out even on relatively small ships.
And he was the leading spirit in acquiring the ship Alpha Helix, which is a floating laboratory, rather small.

goes all over the world and carries out on the spot particularly marine, biochemical, biological investigations that could not be done back home because you need to look at things right then and there.
If you pickle things and bring them back, it's just dead stuff.
So that has set a fantastic example in that field.
Also in physical oceanography and the geological aspects, there's quite a lot you can do on board.
There, I think...
the United States is somewhat lagging behind.
That aspect is much more stressed by nations that have large ships that are comfortable, have laboratories that can operate even when the sea is a little rough, like the USSR.
But an exception from the general rule here is the deep-sea drilling.
Deep-sea drilling is done from big platforms, and therefore they have good laboratories on board, and

much of the important preliminary work is done on shipboard by scientists so that one knows when one comes back directly what one has, and one can do some planning for the next, maybe for the next drill hole from what you get in the first with some sophistication.
Would you, what would you adjudge to be then the more important developments that have occurred in oceanography over the last, let's say since you began,
in terms of analyzing data?

Well, as far as analyzing data goes, there are, of course, a large number of refined instruments that have been developed, very elegant instrumentation that permits much more accurate measurements, and for treatment of the data, then obvious computer developments.
But that is not the most important.
I think the most important is ideas and
completely new techniques that has opened up new realms for investigation.
And there you have again deep sea drilling that's permitted us to look at the ocean in the third dimension.
And that makes, I think, the statement wrong that the exploration of the ocean is over.
Exploration, the first guess at what the very surface looks like of the ocean floor is perhaps done in many areas, not all.
But it's opened up a completely new third dimension.
distribution in depth, the whole geological history of the ocean.
And there is much left to do there.
So that is one of the breakthroughs in new techniques that have opened up completely new vistas in the field.

Other very important developments is the deep toe instrumentation that Professor Spies at this institution has developed, where you can look at the sea floor very closely, and therefore see detail and measure things that you could never even guess at when you
try to do it from the surface as you did in the past.
Those are some of the most important things.
Other important tools, of course, are things like anchored buoys, big buoys that can collect and transmit data continually.
That is a field where only the surface has been scratched, and where an example of
how the lack of measurements at many points at the same time limits our knowledge is the equatorial current system, for example.
There is, as you know, an undercurrent along the equator running under the surface about 50 meters depth, which is fantastically swift.
It's as fast as a Gulf Stream and carries a larger volume of water than the Gulf Stream.
It's one of the most important flows
water in the world.
That plays a crucial role for the whole productivity of the equator.
That is the basis for the enormous fisheries potential and lots of ramifications.
The whole mechanism, the dynamics of that system is very little known, practically unknown, and not very well understood, mainly due to the fact that there have never been
observations at sufficient number of points at the same time that permit you to know where the thing is.

Nobody knows if it's snaking through the ocean, if it separates into blobs, if it undulates like a snake up and down, what the periodicity is of these motions and what is the dynamics of the whole system.
To solve such a problem you have to have either something like a dozen ships operating at the same time
or a large number of buoys or some similar things.

So that is just an example of how synoptic measurements carried out with measurements with a large number of points at the same time for the solution of some of the major problems in the ocean have yet to be done in the future.
What do you see for your future?
Oh, I'm an existentialist, as I told you.
So I'm doing today what I see as the most important things, and I have very little idea where that will lead me tomorrow.
But I'm almost dreaming of coming back sometime for a third take on the problems, again, associated with the equatorial

very exciting equatorial circulation and its effects on sedimentation and on the record in the past because it's one of the most spectacular global mechanisms where the pulse of the Earth essentially is recorded and where you can get an integrated picture of what happened to the Earth as a planet over a very long time and understand how the climatic mechanisms of the Earth
So that is, in oceanography, one of the most interesting things I look forward to.

Another one that we are working on right now, which has somewhat of a social implications, is the resources of the ocean, the mineral resources of the ocean, and their importance for the world, the future world.
That was something I wanted to ask you about.
I was going to ask you in terms of what you thought your major accomplishment was thus far.
What is the mineral potential of the ocean?
Do you answer the guess?
Well, there are several different aspects that are interesting.
There are questions of phosphates, for example, deposited in the relative nearshore area.

But one of the major potential resources discussed today, which is the focus of our interest, also from a scientific point of view, is the huge deposits of copper-nickel ore, copper-nickel incorporated in
the normally more innocuous manganese nodules in a specific narrow zone parallel to the equator, essentially, in the Pacific, and perhaps also in the Indian Ocean.
An ore that, just in one stroke, has doubled the world's known resources of copper and nickel.
And one thing that interests us much, too, is that associated problems.
Everybody realizes, from a resource point of view, that this is important.
The challenge to me lies in
In other associated uses of the deposits that these nodules lie in, they have very interesting characteristics.

And one of the things we have been playing with is to investigate or to develop an interesting type of ceramic from this sediment, which is extremely lightweight, porous, highly insulating, and relatively high flexure strength.
So that is interesting.
building material for earthquake-proof buildings with very high thermal insulation and energy conservation properties.
I don't know if it will ever work out practically.
You never know that with the early developments, but that's a type of interesting secondary approach to new mineral resources on the sea floor.
A sizable number of critics have maintained that the extraction of minerals from the ocean will be so expensive that this sort of resource is limited.
I take it you disagree with that?

Well, I wouldn't know because I'm not an economist, I'm not an engineer, and it's staggering for me to think of the difficulties in designing tools for retrieval of these ores at the necessary rate of
something like a couple of million tons per year for each unit involved.

But I think the best testimony to the practical possibilities is that all of the major mining companies in the world essentially are involved in one of the major consortia that have been formed to explore these possibilities, and that they who are experts in the field
actual practical mining, judge the possibilities good enough so that they have invested many millions of dollars into this and are continuing to do it at an increased rate.

I think when I talk to these people, my friends among them, it is clear that the more conservative among them think that it might be touch and go, but that it's promising enough to pursue for sure at the present time.
I take it then that you feel as if your career will now, again to use that awful word, drift back into the ocean rather than float back out to space.
No, I don't think so.
It will remain in the ocean as it always has been and without being limited to that.
So I foresee to divide my time between problems in the ocean, in the solar system as a whole,
also in more fundamental questions in material science, which interests me very much.
And exactly in terms of material science?
Well, again, there I want to learn and understand better the fundamental properties of the materials that we study and use on the ocean floor.
and that we see forming in space.

These are very complex processes in nature, and you have to look at the underlying more simple processes in the laboratory in order to understand them, and the theory that is developed for more simple things.
So this combination of three fields, I think, is, to my mind, an appealing and productive one.
I just have one more question about
in terms of three fields.
Do you think it will be possible in scientific training in the future for a scientist to switch or to move from field to field, let's say, as you've done, Roger Revelle's done, Isaac's done?
Do you think that will become less possible?
I don't think so.
No, I think if you acquire a good fundamental training, the characteristic of a good fundamental training is that it gives you the tools to

both move in in different fields of science and also to adapt to all the developments that take place in science unless you have such a training and insight then you are lost after 15 years when developers have run away from you so you both must keep in touch both in time and in space with the developments so you see the role will continues as the scientist is journalist as a
Generalist with a broad base sharpened to a point.
Because it's dangerous if you are too general, then it's dangerous you could become a dilettante.
You have to have some things that you really are better in than anybody else.
